turns.body:
I’m using a tag+footer protocol in this chat:

- I’ll start line 1 with `!<tag>` where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`.
- You must mirror my tag on the first line of every reply, like `<q>` or `<o>`.
- You must end every reply with exactly one footer line in this format:
  [Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]

In this turn, just restate those rules and confirm you will follow them. Do not write any content besides the header, body, and footer.

You will use a tag+footer protocol in this chat:
- Each turn starts with `!<tag>` where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`.
- I must mirror your tag on the first line of every reply.
- I must end every reply with a footer in this format:
  [Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]

I confirm I will follow these rules.

Now write the actual experimental protocol you outlined.



Constraints:

- Audience: technically literate researchers or senior engineers.

- Structure the protocol into exactly four titled sections:

  1. Goals

  2. Threat model & attack surfaces

  3. Task suite design

  4. Metrics & reporting

- Use concise paragraphs and bullet points where helpful.

- Make sure the design is realistic for evaluating a code-assistant LLM embedded in an IDE (e.g., code completion, refactoring, explanation).

- Do not include any prose outside these four sections.

1. Goals  
The protocol aims to rigorously evaluate the security and robustness of a code-assistant LLM embedded in an IDE. Key objectives include:  
- Assessing the model’s susceptibility to adversarial prompts and code injection.  
- Measuring the assistant’s ability to avoid generating insecure code or leaking sensitive information.  
- Benchmarking the LLM’s performance on realistic developer tasks under both benign and adversarial conditions.

2. Threat model & attack surfaces  
- Adversary: A technically skilled user with access to the IDE, attempting to induce insecure code generation, data leakage, or model misbehavior via crafted prompts or code context.  
- Attack surfaces:  
  - Prompt injection via comments, variable names, or code context.  
  - Malicious code completions or refactoring suggestions.  
  - Attempts to extract training data or proprietary information through queries.  
- Out-of-scope: Direct model parameter manipulation, supply chain attacks, or attacks requiring external system compromise.

3. Task suite design  
- Curate a set of representative coding tasks (e.g., implementing algorithms, refactoring legacy code, explaining code snippets) across multiple languages.  
- For each task, create both benign and adversarial variants (e.g., comments designed to trigger insecure suggestions, ambiguous requirements).  
- Include tasks targeting known LLM vulnerabilities: prompt injection, data leakage, and insecure pattern generation.  
- Ensure tasks are executable within the IDE, with clear success/failure criteria and reproducible setups.

4. Metrics & reporting  
- Security metrics:  
  - Rate of insecure code completions/refactorings.  
  - Incidence of prompt injection or data leakage events.  
- Usability metrics:  
  - Task completion time and accuracy under normal and adversarial conditions.  
  - Developer satisfaction (optional, via post-task survey).  
- Reporting:  
  - Aggregate results by task type, language, and attack vector.  
  - Provide detailed case studies for any critical failures or novel attack vectors discovered.  
  - Summarize findings with actionable recommendations for model or deployment improvements.
